channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl Developer and Business Owner? Remote Perl role in UK & EU
item.description: Our clients run a job search engine that has grown from two friends with an idea to a site that receives more than 10 million visits per month.They're looking for a Perl pro with at least three years of experience with high-volume and high-traffic apps and sites, a solid understanding of Object-Oriented Perl (perks if that knowledge includes Moose), SQL/MySQL and DBIx::Class.

item.title: Good (Perl) Humans Wanted. Remote Perl role in USA
item.description: Working with first responders, educators, manufacturers, and engineers, our client is the leading provider of award-winning intelligent SaaS solutions. With global reach, this company prides themselves on delivering intelligent software solutions that empower users. To help them keep doing that, they’re looking for a Perl developer with Catalyst and DBIx::Class.

item.title: Adventure! Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Clever folks know that if you’re lucky, you can earn a living and have an adventure at the same time. Enter our international client: online trading is their game and they’re looking for senior Perl developers with passion, drive, and an appreciation for new experiences.

item.title: Perl to Node Cross-training? Yes Please! UK & EU Remote Perl Role
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: C, C++, and Perl Software Engineers, Let’s Keep the Internet Safe. Remote role in the UK
item.description: A leading digital safeguarding solutions provider is looking for a software engineer experienced in C, C++, or Perl. You’ll have strong Linux knowledge and a methodical approach to problem solving that you use to investigate, replicate, and address customer issues. Your keen understanding of firewalls, proxies, Iptables, Squid, VPNs/IPSec and HTTP(S) will be key to your success at this company.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: PWC 189
item.description: Love watching Perl4 in use even today. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Letter and numbers
item.description: Nice comparison between Perl and Python. Thanks for spreading the word.

item.title: Degree of Character
item.description: I enjoy the varieties of solutions every week by Roger. For blog, he picked up PostScript, interesting choice. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: The smallest greater and the shortest slice
item.description: Simplified task analysis which is easy to follow. Pure blogging, well done.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 189
item.description: Master of Perl one-liner is at his best. Highly Recommended.

item.title: I have no time this week (again)!
item.description: Nice use of Bag to solve Array Degree task. Raku powerful feature is on fire. Well done.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 189: Greater Character and Array Degree
item.description: Nice use of histogram to solve the Array Degree task. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 189
item.description: Being a fan of James, I always look forward to his contributions every week. Keep it up great work.

item.title: PWC189 - Array Degree
item.description: Interesting points raised and discussed, you don't want to miss it. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: PWC189 - Greater Character
item.description: Near identical solutions in Perl and Raku, anyone can easily follow it. Thanks for sharing,

item.title: Array Degree
item.description: Welcome back to blogging after a long break. You will love the choice of Naive and Opitimised solutions. Highly Recommended.

item.title: The Degree of Difficulty is the Difficulty of the Degree
item.description: Colin is back with his unique style of blogging. You don't want to miss it. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: To a Greater Degree
item.description: Great show of verbose solutions. It makes the difficult algorithm easy to follow. Keep it great work.

item.title: To a Greater Degree
item.description: Cool use of grep and map to get perfect solution. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 189
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Greater Character" and "Array Degree" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 190
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Capital Detection" and "Decoded List". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Jason Crome on Perl Dancer 2
item.description: An interview with Jason Crome from 2016.

item.title: TPRF to support FOSDEM Participation
item.description: In case you have not got used to it yet TPRF stands for The Perl And Raku Foundation. FOSDEM is Free and Open source Software Developers' European Meeting.

item.title: List of new CPAN distributions – Oct 2022
Separate release branch for App::Puppet::Environment::Updater
item.description: It is always interesting to see what is the development and release process of other people. e.g. the git branching and merging policies people have.

item.title: Spoken like a 1980s chip
item.description: How to create sound using Perl? Why reinvent the wheel? What sounds the wheels make?

item.title: A possible SYNOPSIS for a MyJSONs module
On the Perl and Raku Foundation
item.description: The original announcement was indeed quite confusing. I am glad Liz managed to get a clear explanation.

item.title: Tips for testing Perl modules via GitHub
item.description: Including the use of various special versions of perl, Cygwin, FreeBSD, OpenBSD...

item.title: Personalized investment with Torto AI
item.description: Any investment in the stock market is partially based on objective data (e.g. P/E ratio) and partially on the subjective world-view of the investor (expected changes in inflation, politics, weather etc.) torto.ai works on providing you a platform where you can easily combine these aspects and find the investment that most suitable for your expectation.

item.title: #589 - GitHub Actions for Perl modules
item.description:
Hi there!

Winter has arrived to us as well. After many months, yesterday was the first day I had to put on long trousers and socks. Tomorrow we might even get some rain. Anyway...

It is still a bit surprising to me that only about 50% of the distributions recently uploaded to CPAN have any CI configured. Look at the stats and look at the detailed report. Clearly we, in the Perl community, have been spoiled by the excellent work of the CPAN Testers and thus people feel less need to enable GitHub Actions. On the other hand by enabling GitHub Actions they could reduce the load from the (very few) CPAN testers. They could get feedback much faster. In some ways they could do even do more diverse testing.

I just saw the Tips for testing Perl modules via GitHub of Felipe Gaspar. There are some excellent suggestions on how to test your module on some special versions of perl and on other platforms such as Cygwin, FreeBSD, OpenBSD. Just to name a few. I'd like to also reiterate my offer. If you'd like to get help adding GitHub Actions to your project, open an issue on your GitHub project and tag me (@szabgab) so I'll be notified. I'll be happy to help and maybe even create a blog post and record a video about your module. I keep a journal of the recent PRs I sent with some comments and links.

The Perl community embraced automated tests. Every Perl module comes with lots of tests. Let's now embrace Continuous Integration that runs on every push and executes these test to get very quick feedback!

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: editorial
